body:
### Child abuse or neglect

You shouldn’t make arrangements with the other parent if you have reason to think they’re abusing or neglecting your children.

[Report child abuse](https://www.gov.uk/report-child-abuse-to-local-council) if you have any concerns and tell your children about [Childline](https://www.childline.org.uk/) so they can report any abuse themselves.

You can [report a concern about a child online](https://www.nspcc.org.uk/what-you-can-do/report-abuse/report-abuse-online/) to the National Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Children (NSPCC).

[Find out more about child abuse and neglect](https://www.nspcc.org.uk/preventing-abuse/child-abuse-and-neglect/)

### Domestic violence

Negotiating with the other parent directly won’t be suitable if they pose a threat to you or your children’s safety.

[Report domestic violence](https://www.gov.uk/report-domestic-abuse) if it’s safe to do so and you think you’re a victim.

Find out more about [signs of domestic violence](http://www.refuge.org.uk/get-help-now/what-is-domestic-violence/) if you’re unsure whether you’re a victim.
heading: When negotiating may not be suitable
